DOC.HEAD: The Record Cold Wave Hits Florida, Utilities Ask For Conservation

Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, `The National...' to UPDATE with 73 deaths blamed on cold; INSERTS 1 graf after 13th graf, `Authorities closed ...' to UPDATE with Fla gov. asking Guard to help stranded motorists; INSERTS 1 graf after 23rd graf, `Growers in ...' to UPDATE with estimate of $100 million crop damage in Texas.

DOC.TEXT: Cold and snow burst into Florida on Saturday, threatening fruit and vegetable crops, as Arctic air forced temperatures to more record lows that had utilities and fuel companies scrambling to keep up with demand. Three utilities in Texas had to institute ``rolling blackouts'' because they couldn't keep up with demand for power, with Houston most seriously affected with 150,000 without service Saturday afternoon. Other utilities asked customers to conserve power and shut off service to some commercial clients, and heating oil and propane were high priced and in short supply in some areas. Power was also in short supply in Virginia and Florida. The National Weather Service reported 112 record or record-tying lows, including 31 below zero at Yankton, S.D., the official coldest spot in the Lower 48 states. The frigid weather has been blamed for the deaths of at least 73 people in 26 states since Dec. 15. The toll included 89-year-old Arthur Howze, who was found dead of hypothermia Saturday lying on the floor of his home in front of a small space heater, Lauderdale County Coroner Marl Cobler said. Saturday's low of 26 degrees below zero at Topeka, Kan., was the coldest there for any date since record-keeping began in 1887; the previous record was 25 below in February 1899. Kansas City, Mo., had an all-time low of 23 below zero. The low of 2 below zero at San Angelo, Texas, also was an all-time record. Thirteen Texas cities posted record lows. Low-temperature records for the date also were set or tied in Alabama, Arkansas, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Vermont, Virginia, West Virginia and the District of Columbia. But temperatures in many areas were not quite so low as Friday, and a change was edging in from the West. Jordan, Mont., had a low Saturday of 31, compared with 45 below zero just two days earlier, thanks to Chinook winds blowing down the eastern slopes of the Rockies. At Cut Bank, Mont., on Friday, the temperature rose from 11 below at 11 a.m. to 36 above at noon. Temperatures also rose dramatically Saturday in western South Dakota when a warm front moved through. By 10 a.m., Lemmon, which had dropped to 33 below zero during the week, had a temperature of 37 above zero. Rapid City, which had a record low of 29 below zero Friday, reached 44 above zero by early afternoon Saturday. Snow closed the airport at Wilmington, N.C. ``We've had 10 to 12 inches, but snow drifts are as high as 3 feet,'' said Chuck Holtzinger of the weather service in Wilmington. Two inches of snow fell overnight on the coast of South Carolina, and inland Columbia was forecast to have its first white Christmas since 1935. Snow also fell on parts of southern Georgia. The airport at Savannah, Ga., also closed, because of ice and small snowdrifts, said airport police Officer Lewis Stamper. The Florida Panhandle cities of Pensacola, Tallahassee, Apalachicola, Milton and Crestview were whitened by snow overnight, and 2 inches were forecast for Jacksonville, according to the National Weather Service. Flurries were expected as far south as Miami. Authorities closed icy roads and bridges Saturday across northern Florida, and warned drivers to stay at home. Saturday's low in Pensacola was 18 degrees. Tallahassee and Jacksonville both had 31 degrees. Ice halted traffic on Interstate 75 between Gainesville and the Georgia line, prompting Gov. Bob Martinez to order the National Guard and state agencies to find shelter for stranded travelers, Martinez spokesman Brian Ballard said. The airports in Jacksonville and Gainesville closed Saturday because of ice-covered runways and several flights in and out of Tallahassee were canceled. ``We're taking it hour-by-hour,'' said Ron Beason, Tallahassee manager for USAir. ``People can't get anywhere if they wanted to, so they might as well just stay home,'' said sheriff's spokesman Asa Higgs in Jacksonville, a city of bridges. The Coast Guard rescued 27 hunters and fishermen from bayous and marshes in southern Louisiana, Texas and Mississippi between 7 a.m. Friday and Saturday evening, said Petty Officer Gene Maestas. One fisherman near death from exposure told rescuers in Mississippi his boat sank Dec. 20, Maestas said. In New Orleans, 98 fires, several of them major and most probably caused by portable heaters, broke out between noon Friday and noon Saturday, said fire department Capt. Bob Whitman. ``Pipes are frozen all over town,'' said Joe Giglio, a plumber in Shreveport, La. At Complete Plumbing, Sewer and Drain Service in the New Orleans suburb of Jefferson, 350 people called during the first six hours of business Saturday, but four of the business's 12 plumbers couldn't get their cars started, said secretary Cynthia Peterson. The cold frightened Florida farmers and citrus growers who suffered $3 billion in damages during hard freezes in 1983 and 1985. Must of the citrus crop was still on the trees. ``We've done everything we can to protect it. We've watered it down, got wind machines set up and flash pots fueled up and ready to light if need be,'' said Ben Abbitt, general manager of the Haines City Citrus Growers Cooperative, representing 7,000 acres of citrus groves. ``If it gets cold enough long enough, we've got a disaster,'' said William Moon, sales manager for Zellwin Farms, which has everything from carrots and lettuce to parsley and radishes in the ground in northwestern Orange County.
